title: Homework 1
text:
What do you think being a data scientist is about?
A data scientist is someone who focuses on the process of integrating computers with statistics and business needs. They have a specialization of computing software to be able to gain insights from data, many times in an automated fashion for use with software.


What differences/similarities do you see between data scientists and statisticians?
I view it as starting on the same path and diverging at some point. The root is in statistics, but a statistician will continue with more of the rigor of the field directly, whereas a data scientist will begin to branch off more into the software/development process and application side of things.
Similarities:

Foundational Knowledge
Tool Use

Differences:

Specialized Knowledge
Development Process



How do you view yourself in relation to these two areas?
I am much closer to a data scientist. I have exposure to statistics, but as portions of CSC courses. I have had many courses on directly attributed data science topics and I work in software.


Setting y variable using a column of the iris dataset and density function

y <- density(iris$Petal.Width)




Checking the class, type, and structure of y

class(y)

[1] "density"

typeof(y)

[1] "list"

str(y)

List of 8
 $ x         : num [1:512] -0.656 -0.648 -0.64 -0.633 -0.625 ...
 $ y         : num [1:512] 0.00161 0.00178 0.00197 0.00217 0.00239 ...
 $ bw        : num 0.252
 $ n         : int 150
 $ old.coords: logi FALSE
 $ call      : language density.default(x = iris$Petal.Width)
 $ data.name : chr "iris$Petal.Width"
 $ has.na    : logi FALSE
 - attr(*, "class")= chr "density"





Plotting y, with code hidden with echo=FALSE

title: Homework 3
text:
Load data from data folder

load("../data/hw3/hw2_list.rda")

title: Homework 3
text:
Task 1: Control Flow Practice

Create the status column in both.

bp_list$treatment$status <- character(nrow(bp_list$treatment))
bp_list$placebo$status <- character(nrow(bp_list$placebo))



Fill the treatment with appropriate strings for status

for (i in 1:nrow(bp_list$treatment)) {
  val <- bp_list$treatment[i, "post_bp"]
  bp_str <- ""
  if (val <= 120) {
    bp_str <- "optimal"
  } else if (val <= 130) {
    bp_str <- "borderline"
  } else {
    bp_str <- "high"
  }
  bp_list$treatment[i, "status"] <- bp_str
}
bp_list$treatment$status

 [1] "borderline" "high"       "high"       "borderline" "optimal"   
 [6] "borderline" "borderline" "borderline" "borderline" "borderline"
[11] "high"       "high"       "optimal"    "optimal"    "borderline"
[16] "optimal"    "borderline" "optimal"    "high"       "optimal"   




Fill the placebo with the appropriate string for status

bp_list$placebo$status <- ifelse(bp_list$placebo$post_bp <= 120, "optimal", ifelse(bp_list$placebo$post_bp <= 130, "borderline", "high"))
bp_list$placebo$status

 [1] "optimal"    "high"       "borderline" "borderline" "high"      
 [6] "high"       "high"       "high"       "optimal"    "borderline"

title: Homework 3
text:
Task 2: Function Writing

Build a useful function for the previous usage

my_func <- function(lst, summary_func="mean") {
  # lst needs to be a list with 2 dataframes
  if (!all(is.list(lst), length(lst) == 2, all(sapply(lst, is.data.frame)))) {
    stop("Not a list of 2 data frames")
  }
  # summary_func needs to be one of a set of summary functions (var, sd, min, max, mean)
  summary_funcs <- c("var", "sd", "min", "max", "mean")
  if (!(summary_func %in% summary_funcs)) {
    stop("Not a function")
  }
  summary_function <- get(summary_func)
  
  # lists need to contain pre, post, and diff columns
  cols <- c("pre_bp", "post_bp", "diff_bp")
  if (!all(sapply(lst, function(df) all(cols %in% colnames(df))))) {
    stop("Dataframes don't have the required columns of pre_bp, post_bp, and diff_bp")
  }
  
  return(lapply(lst, function(df) {
    result <-sapply(df[cols], summary_function)
    names(result) <- paste(names(result), summary_func, sep="_")
    return(result)
  }))
}



Apply the function to bp_list with default param, and the other summary funcs

print("default: mean")

[1] "default: mean"

my_func(bp_list)

$treatment
 pre_bp_mean post_bp_mean diff_bp_mean 
      131.60       125.95         5.65 

$placebo
 pre_bp_mean post_bp_mean diff_bp_mean 
       131.9        128.9          3.0 

for (summary_func in c("var", "sd", "min", "max")) {
  print(summary_func)
  print(my_func(bp_list, summary_func))
}

[1] "var"
$treatment
 pre_bp_var post_bp_var diff_bp_var 
   75.72632    78.99737   117.81842 

$placebo
 pre_bp_var post_bp_var diff_bp_var 
   149.8778    124.9889    341.3333 

[1] "sd"
$treatment
 pre_bp_sd post_bp_sd diff_bp_sd 
  8.702087   8.888046  10.854419 

$placebo
 pre_bp_sd post_bp_sd diff_bp_sd 
  12.24246   11.17984   18.47521 

[1] "min"
$treatment
 pre_bp_min post_bp_min diff_bp_min 
        115         114         -24 

$placebo
 pre_bp_min post_bp_min diff_bp_min 
        114         105         -21 

[1] "max"
$treatment
 pre_bp_max post_bp_max diff_bp_max 
        151         146          21 

$placebo
 pre_bp_max post_bp_max diff_bp_max 
        152         143          33

title: Homework 2
text:
Task 1: Basic Vector Practice

1. Pre and Post treatment vectors

pre_treatment <- c(120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)

post_treatment <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)



2. Renamed each

names(pre_treatment) <- paste("Subject", 1:length(pre_treatment), sep = "_")
names(post_treatment) <- paste("Subject", 1:length(post_treatment), sep = "_")

pre_treatment

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       120        151        125        126        115        132        132 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       129        134        139        127        122        127        135 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       133        128        147        138        140        132 

post_treatment

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       127        145        135        122        115        122        123 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       126        126        129        132        146        120        114 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       121        120        128        120        133        115 




3. Difference from pre -> post treatment

delta <- pre_treatment - post_treatment



4. Average change - positive value (positive outcome, blood pressure decreased on average by this amount)

mean(delta)

[1] 5.65




5. Which subjects had a decreased blood pressure?

decrease <- names(which(delta > 0))
decrease

 [1] "Subject_2"  "Subject_4"  "Subject_6"  "Subject_7"  "Subject_8" 
 [6] "Subject_9"  "Subject_10" "Subject_13" "Subject_14" "Subject_15"
[11] "Subject_16" "Subject_17" "Subject_18" "Subject_19" "Subject_20"




6. Which subjects had an decrease in blood pressure ( positive change, but as a subset vector)?

decrease_vector <- delta[delta > 0]
decrease_vector

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         6          4         10          9          3          8         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
         7         21         12          8         19         18          7 
Subject_20 
        17 




7. What is the average decrease of blood pressure of those that had the positive change?

mean(decrease_vector)

[1] 10.6

title: Homework 2
text:
Task 2: Basic Data Frame Practice

1. Create dataframe

data <- data.frame(
  patient = names(pre_treatment),
  pre_bp = pre_treatment,
  post_bp = post_treatment,
  diff_bp = delta,
  row.names=NULL
)
head(data, 1)

    patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
1 Subject_1    120     127      -7




2. Show where diff_bp is negative

title: Homework 2
text:
Task 3: List Practice

1. Create similar dataframe to Task 2

df <- data.frame(
  patient = paste("Subject", 1:10, sep = "_"),
  pre_bp = c(138, 135, 147, 117, 152, 134, 114, 121, 131, 130),
  post_bp = c(105, 136, 123, 130, 134, 143, 135, 139, 120, 124),
  row.names = NULL
)
df$diff_bp <- df$pre_bp - df$post_bp
df$"post_bp < 120" <- df$post_bp < 120
rbind(data_subj = head(data, 2), df_subj = head(df, 2))

              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp post_bp < 120
data_subj.1 Subject_1    120     127      -7         FALSE
data_subj.2 Subject_2    151     145       6         FALSE
df_subj.1   Subject_1    138     105      33          TRUE
df_subj.2   Subject_2    135     136      -1         FALSE




2. Store the 2 data frames into a list.

my_list <- list(treatment=data, placebo=df)
